result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

9:05 AM Defendant Charles M Blair Jr in court.  Attorney Laura Ann Sutton in court for Charles M Blair Jr.  Attorney Aaron B Marcoux in court for State of Wisconsin. Court calls case and appearances. State calls Investigator Jason Bartholomew to the stand. Clerk swears in. State begins questioning. Record reflects the witness has identified the defendant. State continues. Nothing further. Cross from Atty Sutton. Nothing further. Court questions the witness. Redirect from the State. Recross from Atty Sutton. Nothing further. Witness excused. Argument from the State. Argument from Atty Sutton. Court does not find probable cause on the Felony.  Set for status. Bond to continue.
